content.raw:
another way to grow memory footprint:

1. start gzserver
1. start gzclient
1. add PR2 model using gzclient
1. visualize one of the cameras or visualize contacts in gzclient
1. suspend gzclient
1. gzserver memory usage will grow rapidly

Note resuming gzclient process will reduce gzserver memory back to normal, so this is technically not a memory leak.
content.html:
another way to grow memory footprint:

  1. start gzserver
  2. start gzclient
  3. add PR2 model using gzclient
  4. visualize one of the cameras or visualize contacts in gzclient
  5. suspend gzclient
  6. gzserver memory usage will grow rapidly

Note resuming gzclient process will reduce gzserver memory back to normal, so this is technically not a memory leak.

content.raw:
Following John's procedure with the pr2 and using `valgrind --tool=massif gzserver`, it appears that the bulk of the memory consumption occurs as a `std::string::append` in `Connection::EnqueueMsg`.

Here's a selection of the output from the massif tool (`ms_print massif.out.XXXXX`), which shows that 72% of 1.3 GB in the heap is caused by `std::string::append`, which was called from `gazebo::transport::Connection::EnqueueMsg`. The only string append I see in that file is at [Connection.cc:291](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6564bf34fc453f7d5a7aaa06ca18073d0a2d10cf/gazebo/transport/Connection.cc?at=gazebo_1.8#cl-291)
~~~
99.19% (1,322,980,240B) (heap allocation functions) malloc/new/new[], --alloc-fns, etc.
->78.74% (1,050,272,191B) 0x745CA87: std::string::_Rep::_S_create(unsigned long, unsigned long, std::allocator<char> const&) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.16)
| ->74.67% (995,997,809B) 0x745D7F9: std::string::_Rep::_M_clone(std::allocator<char> const&, unsigned long) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.16)
| | ->74.66% (995,885,263B) 0x745D8DE: std::string::reserve(unsigned long) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.16)
| | | ->72.26% (963,773,555B) 0x745DE0B: std::string::append(std::string const&) (in /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6.0.16)
| | | | ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x564D8C7: gazebo::transport::Connection::EnqueueMsg(std::string const&, bool) (basic_string.h:925)
| | | | | ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x5677C13: gazebo::transport::SubscriptionTransport::HandleData(std::string const&) (SubscriptionTransport.cc:55)
| | | | | | ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x56718CB: gazebo::transport::Publication::Publish(boost::shared_ptr<google::protobuf::Message>, boost::function<void ()()> const&) (Publication.cc:304)
| | | | | |   ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x5678108: gazebo::transport::TopicManager::Publish(std::string const&, boost::shared_ptr<google::protobuf::Message>, boost::function<void ()()> const&) (TopicManager.cc:205)
| | | | | |     ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x567676C: gazebo::transport::Publisher::SendMessage() (Publisher.cc:188)
| | | | | |       ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x566CC24: gazebo::transport::Node::ProcessPublishers() (Node.cc:138)
| | | | | |         ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x5678AD0: gazebo::transport::TopicManager::ProcessNodes(bool) (TopicManager.cc:155)
| | | | | |           ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x5662821: gazebo::transport::ConnectionManager::RunUpdate() (ConnectionManager.cc:279)
| | | | | |             ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x5663A20: gazebo::transport::ConnectionManager::Run() (ConnectionManager.cc:310)
| | | | | |               ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x6D48CE7: thread_proxy (in /usr/lib/libboost_thread.so.1.46.1)
| | | | | |                 ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x61D0E98: start_thread (pthread_create.c:308)
| | | | | |                   ->72.25% (963,657,600B) 0x79C7CBB: clone (clone.S:112)
~~~

Here's a selection of the output from the massif tool (ms_print massif.out.XXXXX), which shows that 72% of 1.3 GB in the heap is caused by std::string::append, which was called from gazebo::transport::Connection::EnqueueMsg. The only string append I see in that file is at Connection.cc:291

content.raw: I've tested with a few old versions of gazebo from debs ([1.8.0](http://gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/gazebo_1.8.0-1~precise_amd64.deb), [1.8.2](http://gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/gazebo_1.8.2-1~precise_amd64.deb), and the [nightly from yesterday](http://gazebosim.org/assets/distributions/gazebo-nightly_1.8.2~hg20130603rdd0c360c302b-1~precise_amd64.deb)), and they all exhibit this same problem, and they have more memory leaks. So this isn't a new problem that was introduced by yesterday's release.
content.html: I've tested with a few old versions of gazebo from debs (1.8.0, 1.8.2, and the nightly from yesterday), and they all exhibit this same problem, and they have more memory leaks. So this isn't a new problem that was introduced by yesterday's release.
